page.title: 05History Procurators House
page.content: The Procurators house in Magor is one of only two known examples in Britain,the other being Chesterton Towers near Cambridge. When Gilbert Marshall,Earl of Pembroke and Lord of Chepstow bestowed the church of Magor and its income upon the abbot and Convent of Santa Maria Di Gloria in Central Italy in 1238, the abbey appointed a procurator,a certain Deodatus,to act in the capacity of agent or steward for the Monastery,collecting the rents and other dues of the church of Magor,including tythes,and transferring the profits to Anagni in Italy.As a centre for his work,the procurator built himself a fine house, and even today it's ruins give us some indication of its original importance in the life and work of the parish.
